articles.headline: Shiite Rivalries Slash at a Once Calm Iraqi City
articles.snippet: Unrest in Diwaniya reflects a new landscape in which Shiite groups no longer look to politics to allocate power.
articles.abstract: Unrest in Diwaniya reflects a new landscape in which Shiite groups no longer look to politics to allocate power.
articles.lead_paragraph: DIWANIYA, Iraq — The Shiite heartland of southern Iraq has generally been an oasis of calm in contrast to Baghdad and the central part of the country, but now violence is convulsing this city. Shiites are killing and kidnapping other Shiites, the police force is made up of competing militias and the inner city is a web of impoverished streets where idealized portraits of young men, killed in recent gun battles with Iraqi and American troops, hang from signposts above empty lots.

articles.headline: Fast, Dazzling, Large and Deluxe
articles.snippet: A plan to build the world’s first supersonic business jet is the latest sign that business jets are becoming the fastest-growing segment of the aerospace industry.
articles.abstract: A plan to build the world’s first supersonic business jet is the latest sign that business jets are becoming the fastest-growing segment of the aerospace industry.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS, June 20 — The Texas billionaire Robert M. Bass is not the kind of guy who flies commercial. If his latest venture takes to the skies, he will not be the kind who flies subsonic either.

articles.headline: Congress Weighs End to Private Equity Tax Break
articles.snippet: The little-known tax break has allowed wealthy financiers to cut their total income tax bills by billions of dollars.
articles.abstract: The little-known tax break has allowed wealthy financiers to cut their total income tax bills by billions of dollars.
articles.lead_paragraph: Leaders of the tax-writing committees in Congress are considering a new proposal to end a little-known tax break that has allowed wealthy financiers who run private equity firms and hedge funds to cut their total income tax bills by billions of dollars, aides to lawmakers say.
articles.byline: By Jenny Anderson and Andrew Ross Sorkin

articles.headline: Digital S.L.R.’s That Let You Shoot Like a Pro
articles.snippet: The choice among new S.L.R. cameras from Canon, Nikon, Pentax, Olympus and Sony comes down to price, features and your existing lens collection.
articles.abstract: The choice among new S.L.R. cameras from Canon, Nikon, Pentax, Olympus and Sony comes down to price, features and your existing lens collection.
articles.lead_paragraph: To an ordinary person, the summer might mean barbecues, baseball games and trips to the beach. To a photography nut, however, it means longer days of sunlight, brighter subject colors (beach balls, bathing suits) and more people who don’t have to be told to “Smile!”

articles.headline: For 2 Years, Bloomberg Aides Prepared for Bid
articles.snippet: Aides to Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg of New York have laid the groundwork for a potential independent run for president.
articles.abstract: Aides to Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg of New York have laid the groundwork for a potential independent run for president.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 20 — The announcement by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg of New York that he was leaving the Republican Party to become an independent was made after nearly two years in which his aides had laid the groundwork for a potential independent run for president.
articles.byline: By Adam Nagourney and Jim Rutenberg

articles.headline: At Wal-Mart, a Back Door Into Banking
articles.snippet: Wal-Mart failed to get approval for a bank. But the giant discount chain is effectively building one anyway.
articles.abstract: Wal-Mart failed to get approval for a bank. But the giant discount chain is effectively building one anyway.
articles.lead_paragraph: Wal-Mart failed to get approval for a bank. But the giant discount chain is effectively building one anyway.
articles.byline: By Michael Barbaro and Eric Dash

articles.headline: New Orleans Still at Risk, Army Data Show
articles.snippet: In block-by-block detail, a report shows that despite improvement, a big storm would still be likely to flood large areas of the city.
articles.abstract: In block-by-block detail, a report shows that despite improvement, a big storm would still be likely to flood large areas of the city.
articles.lead_paragraph: After nearly two years of work, the Army Corps of Engineers revealed yesterday which New Orleans neighborhoods and blocks were the most vulnerable to flooding, and which were the best protected. The report shows that despite considerable improvement, large swaths of the city are still likely to be flooded in a major storm.

articles.headline: Few Choices for Workers at Dow Jones
articles.snippet: Some at The Wall Street Journal are calling the decision between potential bidders a choice between “trash or slash.”
articles.abstract: Some at The Wall Street Journal are calling the decision between potential bidders a choice between “trash or slash.”
articles.lead_paragraph: Looking at the potential bidders for Dow Jones & Company  Rupert Murdoch’s News Corporation and a joint effort by General Electric and Pearson  some reporters and editors at The Wall Street Journal are calling the decision a choice between “trash or slash.” And they are wondering which might be worse.

articles.headline: Bear Stearns Staves Off Collapse of 2 Hedge Funds
articles.snippet: But questions remain about how successful the bank was and whether it had merely delayed the inevitable.
articles.abstract: But questions remain about how successful the bank was and whether it had merely delayed the inevitable.
articles.lead_paragraph: The high-stakes game of brinksmanship began early yesterday on Wall Street, and continued throughout the day. Bankers traded telephone calls, frenetically negotiating the fate of two hedge funds.
articles.byline: By Vikas Bajaj and Julie Creswell

articles.headline: Giuliani May See a Rival in Successor
articles.snippet: Rudolph W. Giuliani helped Michael R. Bloomberg get elected; now they could face off as presidential candidates.
articles.abstract: Rudolph W. Giuliani helped Michael R. Bloomberg get elected; now they could face off as presidential candidates.
articles.lead_paragraph: Seven weeks after the 2001 terror attacks, Rudolph W. Giuliani gave a last-minute electoral nod to a billionaire media mogul running for mayor.
